utterance: "Well," said the other curtly, "it's the law, Bill Chadwick, and it must be carried out. We've got our orders."

utterance: "Oh, yes! You are the commander, Cap'n Moseley, an' I'm the army. Ain't I the gayest army you ever had under you? I'll tell you what, Cap'n Moseley (I'd call you Dick, like I useter, if we was n't in the ranks), when I j'ined the army I thought I was goin' to fight the Yankees, but they slapped me in the camp of instruction over there at Adairsville, an' now here we are fightin' our own folks. If we ain't fightin' 'em, we are pursuin' after 'em, an' runnin' 'em into the woods an' up the mountains. Now what kind of a soldier will one of these conscripts make? You need n't tell me Cap'n! The law won't pan out."
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: "But it's the law," said Captain Moseley.
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: "They tell me," he said, "that it's a heap easier to make a bad law than it is to make a good one. It takes a lot of smart men a long time to make a good one, but a passel of blunderbusses can patch a bad one up in a little or no time. That's the way I look at it.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: What's the name of this chap we are after? Israel Spurlock? I'd like to know, by George, what's the matter with him! They yerked him into army, an' he yerked himself out, an' now the word is that the war can't go on unless Israel Spurlock is on hand to fling down his gun an' run when he hears a bungshell playin' a tune in the air."
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: "It's jest like I tell you, Cap'n. The news is that we had a terrible victory at Chattanooga, but I notice in the Atlanta papers that the Yankees ain't no further north than they was before the fight; an' what makes it wuss, they are warmin' themselves in Chattanooga, whilst we are shiverin' outside. I reckon if Israel Spurlock had been on hand at the right time an' in the right place, we'd a drove the Yanks plumb back to Nashville. Lord! I hope we 'll have him on the skirmish line the next time we surround the enemy an' drive him into a town as big as Chattanooga."

He weren't much of a preacher on his own hook, but let 'im foller along for to clench the sermon, an' his match could n't be foun' in them days. Yit, Jerry was a man of peace, an' here's his son a-gwine about with guns an' pistols, an' what not, a-tryin' to give peaceable folks a smell of war."

An' yit," the old man continued, looking up at the captain with a smile that well became his patriarchal face, "thar ain't a cabin on the hill whar you won't be more than welcome. Yes, sir; wheresomeever you find a h'a'thstone, thar you'll find a place to rest."

utterance: "So I have heard," said the captain. "But maybe you can cut our journey short. We have a message for Israel Spurlock."

He was weakly like from the time he was a boy, an' when I heard you call forth his name, I allowed to myself, says I, 'Israel Spurlock is sick, an' they've come atter his ole mammy to go an' nuss him.' utterance: "Oh, yes! Business here an' war yander. I hear tell that you er after Israel Spurlock. Lord A'mighty above us! What er you after Israel for? He hain't got no niggers for to fight for. All the fightin' he can do is to fight for his ole mammy."
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "Oh, I know who sent you!"
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "Who?"
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: "Nobody but Wesley Lovejoy!"
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "Come, now, hain't it so? Did n't Wesley Lovejoy send you?"
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "Well, a man named Lovejoy is on Colonel Waring's staff, and he gave me my orders."
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: "What is the matter with Lovejoy?"
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: "Oh, wait! thes wait. You may n't want to wait, but you'll have to. I may look like I'm mighty puny, an' I 'spec' I am, but I hain't dead yit. Lord A'mighty, no! Not by a long shot!"
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "I wonder wher' Polly is, an' what she's a-doin'?"
speaker: Aunt Crissy
addressee: Captain Moseley, Private Chadwick, and Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: "Don't pester 'long of Polly. She knows what she's a-doin'."
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "About this Wesley Lovejoy, you seem to know him very well."
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: "You hear that, William! He asts me ef I know Wes. Lovejoy! Do I know him? Why, the triflin' houn'! I've knowed him ev'ry sence he was big enough to rob a hen-roos'."
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "Lord A'mighty! I know how you feel, an' I don't blame you for feelin' so; but don't you go up the mountain this night. Thes stay right whar you is, beca'se ef you don't you'll make all your friends feel bad for you. Don't ast me how, don't ast me why. Thes you stay. Come an' put me to bed, William, an' don't let these folks go out 'n the house this night."
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: "I wonder wher' Polly is, an' what she's a-doin'?"
speaker: Aunt Crissy
addressee: Uncle Billy Powers, Captain Moseley, and Private Chadwick

utterance: "Did anybody ever hear the beat of that? Run, Iserl, an' see what it is that's a-tryin' to tear the roof off 'n the house."
speaker: Old Mrs. Spurlock

utterance: "'Polly!'"
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "In the name er the Lord! wher' 'd you drop from? You look more like a drownded ghost than you does like folks. Come right in here an' dry yourse'f. What in the name of mercy brung you out in sech weather? Who's dead or a-dyin'? Why, look at the gal! Have they come?"
speaker: Old Mrs. Spurlock

utterance: "Listen at 'er, Iserl! I b'lieve in my soul she's done gone an' run ravin' deestracted. Shake 'er, Iserl; shake 'er."
speaker: Old Mrs. Spurlock

utterance: "An' jest to think that that there good-for-nothin' Wesley Lovejoy had the imperdence to ast me to have him no longer 'n last year, an' he's been a-flyin' round me constant."
speaker: Polly
addressee: Old Mrs. Spurlock and Israel Spurlock

utterance: "I seed him a-droppin' his wing. I reckon that's the reason he's after me so hot. But never you mind, mammy; you thes look after the gal that's gwine to be your daughter-in-law, an' I'll look after your son."
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "Go off, you goose! Ef they hang you, whose daughter-in-law will I be then?"
speaker: Polly

utterance: "The Lord knows! They tell me that Lovejoy is an orphan!'"
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "You must be crazy. I hope you don't think I'd marry that creetur. I would n't look at him if he was the last man. You better be thinkin' about your goozle."
speaker: Polly

utterance: "It's ketchin' befo' hangin',"
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "They 've mighty nigh got you now,"
speaker: Polly

utterance: "You thought they had me then,"
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "Oh, I wisht you'd cut an' run; they'll be here therreckly."
speaker: Polly

utterance: "This business puzzles me I jest tell you it does. That Wes. Lovejoy done like he was the best friend I had. He was constantly huntin' me up in camp, an' when I told him I would like to come home an' git mammy's crap in, he jest laughed an' said he did n't reckon I'd be missed much, an' now he's a-houndin' me down. What has the man got agin me?"
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "Oh, I do wisht you'd go on; them men'll shorely ketch you ef you keep on a-stayin' here a-winkin' an' a-gwine on makin' monkey motions."
speaker: Polly

utterance: "Shoo! Ef the house was surrounded by forty thousan' of 'em, I'd git by 'em, an', ef need be, take you wi' me."
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "Sh-sh-sh! Don't make no fuss. The dogs has been a-barkin' at sperits an' things. Jest keep right still."
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "I'm goin' up to the Rock, an' light the fire. Maybe the boys 'll see it, an' maybe they won't. Leastways they 're mighty apt to smell the smoke."
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: "Halt! Who goes there?"
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: "Nobody ner nothin' that 'll bite you, I reckon,"
speaker: Polly

utterance: "What can that be?"
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: "What did you say it was?"
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: "It's jest a fire, I reckon. Ef it's a house burnin' down, it can't be holp. Water could n't save it now."
speaker: Polly

utterance: "I tell you what, Captain, that gal's a slick 'un. It's my belief that we are gwine on a fool's errand. 'Stead of gwine towards Spurlock, we're gwine straight away from 'im. When that gal made her disappearance last night she went an' found Spurlock, an' ef he ain't a natchul born fool he tuck to the woods. Why, the shawl the gal had on her head this mornin' was soakin' wet. It were n't rainin', an' had n't been for a right smart while. How come the shawl wet? They were n't but one way
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: What is to be done, then?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Well, the Lord knows what ought to be done, but I reckon the best plan is to sorter scatter out an' skirmish aroun' a little bit. We'd better divide our army. You go up the mountain an' git Spurlock, if he's up thar, an' let me take my stan' on the ridge yander an' keep my eye on Uncle Billy's back yard an' hoss lot. If Spurlock is r'ally tuck to the woods, he'll be mighty apt to be slinkin' 'roun' whar the gal is.
speaker: Chadwick

utterance: I was a-spinnin' away for dear life, when all of a sudden I hearn a fuss, an' I 'lows ter myself, says I, 'I'll be boun' that's some one a-hailin',' says I; an' then I dropped ever'thin' an' run ter the door an' shore enough it was. Won't you 'light an' come in?
speaker: Old Mrs. Spurlock

utterance: Is Mr. Israel Spurlock at home?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Not, as you might say, adzackly at home, but I reckon in reason it won't be long before he draps in. He hain't had his breakfas' yit, though hit's been a-waitin' for him tell hit's stone col'. The cows broke out last night, an' he went off a-huntin' of 'em time it was light good. Iserl is thes ez rank after his milk ez some folks is after the'r dram. I says, says I, 'Shorely you kin do 'thout your milk one mornin' in the year; but he would n't nigh hear ter that. He thes up an' bolted off.
speaker: Old Mrs. Spurlock

utterance: I'll ride on. Maybe I'll meet him coming back. Good-by.
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Have you seen Israel Spurlock this morning?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: No, sir, I hain't saw him.
speaker: one

utterance: Have you seen Israel Spurlock?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Yes! Oh, yes! Goodness gracious, yes!
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Where is he now?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: All about. Yes! All around! Gracious, yes!
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Here's his track right now! Oh, yes! Right fresh, too! Goodness, yes!
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Where are you going?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Well, blame my scaly hide! You're the identical man I'm a-huntin'.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: An' now you're sorry you went an' foun' me, I reckon.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: Well, I ain't as glad as I 'lowed I'd be. Yit nuther am I so mighty sorry. One way or 'nother I knowed in reason I'd run up on you.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: You're mighty right. You fell in my arms same as a gal in a honeymoon. Lemme lift you up, as the mule said when he kicked the nigger over the fence. Maybe you'll look purtier when you swap een's.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: You ketched me that time, certain and shore, they ain't no two ways about that. I was a-settin' on the log thar, a-noddin' an' a-dreamin' 'bout Christmas. 'T ain't many days off, I reckon.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Oh, yes! a mighty purty dream, I bet a hoss. You was fixin' up for to cram me in Lovejoy's stockin'. A mighty nice present I'd 'a' been, tooby shore. Stidder hangin' up his stockin', Lovejoy was a-aimin' for to hang me up. Oh, yes! Christmas dreams is so mighty nice an' fine, I'm a great min' to set right down here an' have one er my own -one of them kin' er dreams what's got forked tail an' fireworks mixed up on it.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: Well, whose stockin' is you a-gwine to cram me in?
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: In whose else's but Danny Lemmons's? An' won't he holler an' take on? Why, I would n't miss seein' Danny Lemmons take on for a hat full er shinplasters. Dang my buttons ef I would!
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: Lord! don't ast me about Danny Lemmons. He's he's well, I tell you what, he's the bull er the woods, Danny Lemmons is; nuther more ner less. He hain't bigger 'n my two fists, an' he's 'flicted, an' he's all crippled up in his back, whar he had it broke when he was a baby, an' yit he's in-about the peartest man on the mountain, an' he's the toughest an' the sooplest. An' more 'n that, he's got them things up here,
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: What's your will wi' me?
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Well, I'm a-gwine to empty your gun, an' tote your pistol for you, an' invite you down to Uncle Billy's. Oh, you need n't worry, they're expectin' of you. Polly's tol' 'em you'd likely come back.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: How did Polly know?
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Danny Lemmons tol' 'er.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: By George! the woods is full of Danny Lemmons.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Why, bless your heart, he thes swarms roun' here.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: I see he's ketched you, Iserl. He 'lowed las' night as how he'd fetch you back wi' him.
speaker: Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: Yes, he thes crope up on me. It's mighty hard for to fool these army fellers.
speaker: Israel Spurlock

utterance: Now, I do hope an' trust he ain't gone an' lost his temper up thar in the woods. I hope it from the bottom of my heart. These here wars an' rumors of wars makes the folks mighty restless. They'll take resks now what they would n't dassent to of tuck before this here rippit begun, an' it's done got so now human life ain't wuth shucks. The boys up here ain't no better 'n the rest. They fly to pieces quicker 'n they ever did.
speaker: Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: It is enough, by George! to make a sensible man sick.
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Lord, yes! That's what I tell 'em; goodness, yes!
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Now, look here! Are you following me, or am I following you? I don't want to be dogged after in the bushes, much less in the big road.
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Ner me nurther. An' then thar's Spurlock - Lord, yes; I hain't axt him about it, but I bet a hoss he don't like to be dogged atter nuther.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: My friend, you seem to have a quick tongue. What is your name?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Danny Lemmons. Now don't say I look like I ought to be squoze. Ever'body inginer'lly says that, but I've squoze lots more than what's ever squoze me. Lord, yes! Yes, siree! Men an' gals ter-gether. You ax 'em, an' they'll tell you.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Lemmons, Well, you look it!
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Boo! you don't know what you 're a-talkin' about. The gals all 'low I'm mighty sweet. You ought to see me when I'm rigged out in my Sunday-go-to-meetin' duds. Polly Powers she 'lows I look snatchin'. Lord, yes! Yes, siree! I'm gwine down to Polly's house now.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Well, boys, I hope you are not tired waiting for me.
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: No, we was thes a-settin' here talkin' 'bout ol' times. We 'lowed maybe you'd sorter git tangled up on the hill thar, and so Danny Lemmons, he harked back for to keep a' eye on you.
speaker: one

utterance: I'll tell you what, they ain't a man on the mounting that's got a blessed thing agin you, ner agin the tother feller, an' they hain't a man anywheres aroun' here that 's a-gwine to pester you. We never brung you whar you is; but now that you're here we're a-gwine to whirl in an' ast you to stay over an' take Christmas wi' us, sech ez we 'll have. Lord, yes! a nice time we 'll have, ef I ain't forgot how to finger the fiddle-strings. We're sorter in a quandary, We don't know whether you're a-gwine to be worried enough to start a row, or whether you're a-gwine to work up trouble.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Now, then, thes make yourself at home.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Brethern, we 're gethered here for to praise the Lord an' do his will. The quare times that's come on us has brung us face to face with much that is unseemly in life, an' likely to fret the sperit an' vex the understandin'. Yit the Almighty is with us, an' of us, an' among us; an', in accordance wi' the commands delivered in this Book, we're here to fortify two souls in the'r choice, an' to b'ar testimony to the Word that makes lawful marriage a sacrament.
speaker: Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: It ain't any use, to call the roll. We're all here an' accounted for. The only man or woman that can't answer to their name is Danny Lemmons's little brown fiddle, an' I'll bet a sev'm-punce it'd skreak a little ef he tuck it out 'n the bag. But before we whirl in an' make a charge three deep, le' 's begin right. This is Christmas, and that bowl yander, with the egg-nog in it, looks tired. Good as the dinner is, it's got to have a file leader. We'll start in with what looks the nighest like Christmas.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Well, I've been in sech a swivet all day I don't reelly reckon the nog is wuth your while, but you'll ha' ter take it thes like you fin' it. Hit's sweetened wi' long sweet'nin', an' it'll ha' ter be dipped up wi' a gourd an' drunk out 'n cups.
speaker: Aunt Crissy

utterance: Lord bless you, ma'am, they won't be no questions axed ef it's got Christmas enough in it, an' I reckon it is, kaze I poured it in myself, an' I can hol' up a jug as long as the nex' man.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Ef I had n't 'a' been a prisoner of war, as you may say, I'd 'a' got me a hunk of barbecue an' a dumplin' or two, an' a slice of that chicken pie there - I'd 'a' grabbed 'em up an' 'a' made off down the mountain. Why, I'll tell you what's the truth-I got a whiff of that barbecue by daylight, an' gentulmen, it fairly made me dribble at the mouth. Nex' to Uncle Billy there, I was the fust man at the pit.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Yes, yes, that's so. An' you holp me a right smart. I'll say that.
speaker: Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: An' Spurlock, he got a whiff of it. Didn't you all notice, about the time he was gittin' married, how his mouth puckered up? Along towards the fust I thought he was fixin' to dip down an' give the bride a smack. But, bless you, he had barbecue on his min', an' the bride missed the buss.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: He did n't dare to buss me. Leastways not right out there before you all.
speaker: Polly

utterance: Please, ma'am, don't you be skeered of Iserl. I kin take a quarter of that shote an' tole him plumb back to camp.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Now I don't like the looks er this. Come, boys, this won't do. I don't want to remember the time when any livin' human bein' sot at my table on Christmas day with his han's tied. Come, now!
speaker: Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: Why, tooby shore! Turn the poor creetur loose.
speaker: Aunt Crissy

utterance: Jest try it!
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: Lord, no. Look at his eyes! Look at 'em.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: What does Moseley say?
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: Ah, he is your prisoner. He never struck me as a dangerous man.
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Well, ef there's any doubt, jest take 'im out in the yard an' give 'im han'-roomance. Don't let 'im turn this table over, 'cause it 'll be a long time before some of this company 'll see the likes of it ag'in.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Well, boys, this is my house, an' he's at my table. I reckon we better ontie 'im, an' let 'im git a mou'ful ter eat. 'T ain't nothin' but Christian-like.
speaker: Uncle Billy Powers

utterance: Don't you reckon he'd better eat at the second table?
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: I reckon this fork 'll have to be washed.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Do you s'pose I raised Danny Lemmons for the like of that?
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: Well, it beats the known worl'. It's the fust time I ever seed a man git down on the floor for to give the in-turn an' the under-cut, an' cut the pigeon-wing an' the double-shuffle, all before a cat could bat her eye. It looks to me that as peart a man as Lemmons there ought to be in the war.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Ain't he in the war? Ain't he forever and eternally in the war? Ain't he my bully bushwhacker?
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: On what side?
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: The Union, the Union!
speaker: Colonel Dick Watson

utterance: Well, ef you think you kin take the taste out 'n this barbecue with talk like that, you are mighty much mistaken.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: What about Lovejoy?
speaker: Captain Moseley

utterance: Oh, bless you! he goes over the mountain.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Lord, yes! Right over the mountain.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Now, I say no. Turn the man loose an' let him go.
speaker: Polly

utterance: You see 'im now!
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: You see what he was atter! He'd better have gone over the mountain. Lord, yes! Lots better.
speaker: Danny Lemmons

utterance: Damn him! he's got what he's been a-huntin' for.
speaker: Bill Chadwick

utterance: Howdy, boss?
speaker: Ananias

utterance: I'm name' Ananias, suh.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Well, Ananias is a good name.
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Yasser, dat w'at mammy say. Mammy done dead now, but she say dat dey wuz two Ananiases. Dey wuz ole Ananias en young Ananias. One un um wuz de Liar, en de udder wuz de Poffit. Dat w'at mammy say. I'm name' atter de Poffit.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Where are you going?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Who? Me? I'm gwine back ter Marster, suh.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: What is your master's name?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Cunnel Benjamime Flewellen, suh.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Colonel Benjamin Flewellen; yes; I know the colonel well. What are you going back there for?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Who? Me? Dat my home, suh. I bin brung up right dar, suh — right 'long-side er Marster en my young mistiss, suh.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Miss Ellen Flewellen,
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Yasser, dat her name, sho; but we-all call her Miss Nelly.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: A very pretty name, Ananias,
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Lord! yasser.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Where have you been, Ananias?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Who? Me? I bin 'long wid Sherman army, suh.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Then you are quite a soldier by this time.
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Lord! yasser! I bin wid um fum de time dey come in dese parts plum tell dey got ter Sander'ville. You ain't never is bin ter Sander' ville, is you, boss?
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Not to say right in the town, Ananias, but I've been by there a great many times.
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Well, suh, don't you never go dar; special don't you go dar wid no army, kase hit 's de longes' en de nasties' road fum dar ter yer w'en you er comin' back, dat I ever is lay my two eyes on.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Why did you come back, Ananias?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Who? Me? Well, suh, w'en de army come 'long by home dar, look like eve'ybody got der eye sot on me. Go whar I would, look alike all de folks wuz a-watchin' me. 'Bout time de army wuz a-pilin' in on us, Marse Wash Jones, w'ich I never is done 'im no harm dat I knows un, he went ter Marster, he did, en he 'low dat ef dey don't keep mighty close watch on Ananias dey'd all be massycreed in deir beds. I know Marse Wash tol' Marster dat, kaze Ma'y Ann, w'ich she wait on de table, she come right outer de house en tol' me so. Right den, suh, I 'gun ter feel sorter skittish. Marster had done got me ter hide all de stock out in de swamp, en I 'low ter myse'f, I did, dat I'd des go over dar en stay wid um. I ain't bin dar so mighty long, suh, w'en yer come de Yankees, en wid um wuz George, de carriage driver, de nigger w'at Marster think mo' uv dan he do all de bal-ance er his niggers. En now, den, dar wuz George a-fetchin' de Yankees right whar he know de stock wuz hid at.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: George was a very handy negro to have around,
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Yasser. Marster thunk de worl' en all er dat nigger, en dar he wuz showin' de Yankees whar de mules en hosses wuz hid at. Well, suh, soon ez he see me, George he put out, en I staid dar wid de hosses. I try ter git dem folks not ter kyar um off, I beg um en I plead wid um, but dey des laugh at me, suh. I follered 'long atter um', en dey driv dem hosses en mules right by de house. Marster wuz standin' out in de front porch, en w'en he see de Yankees got de stock, en me 'long wid um, suh, he des raise up his han's-so en drap um down by his side, en den he tuck 'n tu'n
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Well, what did you do?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Who? Me? Well, suh, I des crope off ter my cabin, en I draw'd up a cheer front er de fier, en stirred up de embers, en sot dar. I ain' sot dar long 'fo' Marster come ter de do'. He open it, he did, en he come in. He 'low, 'You in dar, Ananias?' I say, 'Yasser.' Den he come in. He stood dar, he did, en look at me. I ain't raise my eyes, suh; I des look in de embers. Bime-by he say, 'Ain't I allers treat you well, Ananias?' I 'low, 'Yasser.' Den he say, 'Ain't I raise you up fum a little baby, w'en you got no daddy?' I 'low,' Yasser.' He say, How come you treat me dis a-way, Ananias? W'at make you show dem Yankees whar my hosses en mules is?
speaker: Ananias

utterance: You in dar, Ananias?
speaker: Colonel Benjamin Flewellen

utterance: Yasser.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Ain't I allers treat you well, Ananias?
speaker: Colonel Benjamin Flewellen

utterance: Yasser.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Ain't I raise you up fum a little baby, w'en you got no daddy?
speaker: Colonel Benjamin Flewellen

utterance: Yasser.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: How come you treat me dis a-way, Ananias? W'at make you show dem Yankees whar my hosses en mules is?
speaker: Colonel Benjamin Flewellen

utterance: What did you tell him?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Well, suh, I dunner w'at de name er God come 'cross me. I wuz dat full up dat I can't talk. I tried ter tell Marster des 'zactly how it wuz, but look like I wuz all choke up. White folks kin talk right straight 'long, but niggers is diffunt. Marster stood dar, he did, en look at me right hard, en I know by de way he look dat his feelin's wuz hurted, en dis make me wuss. Eve'y time I try ter talk, suh, sumpin' ne'r kotch me in de neck, en 'fo' I kin come ter myse'f, suh, Marster wuz done gone. I got up en tried ter holler at 'im, but dat ketch wuz dar in my neck, suh, en mo' special wuz it dar, suh, w'en I see dat he wuz gwine 'long wid his head down; en dey mighty few folks, suh, dat ever is see my marster dat a-way. He kyar his head high, suh, ef I do say it myse'f.
speaker: Ananias

utterance: Why didn't you follow after him and tell him about it?
speaker: Lawyer Terrell

utterance: Dat des zactly w'at I oughter done, suh; but right den en dar I ain't know w'at ter do. I know'd dat nigger like me ain't got no business foolin' 'roun' much, en dat wuz all I did know. I march wid um, suh, plum tell dey got ter Sander'ville, en dar I ax um w'at dey gwine pay me fer gwine wid um. Well, suh, you may n't b'lieve me, but dem w'ite mens dey des laugh at me. All dis time I bin runnin' over in my min' 'bout Marster en Miss Nelly, en w'en I fin' out dat dey wa'n't no pay fer niggers gwine wid de army I des up en say ter myse'f dat dat kind er business ain't gwine do fer me.

She de mos' no 'countest nigger gal what I ever laid my two eyes on. I'm name' Jesse, ma'm, en I use' ter b'long ter de Bascom fambly when I wuz a boy. Is you ready fer breakfus, Mistiss?
speaker: Jesse

utterance: Has my father-has Judge Bascom employed you?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: No'm, dat he ain't! I des come my own se'f, kaze I know'd in reason you wuz gwine ter be in needance er somebody. Lord, no 'm, none er de Bascoms don't hafter hire me, ma'm.
speaker: Jesse

utterance: And who told you to send Elvira away?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Nobody ain't tell me, ma'm, When I come she wuz des settin' in dar by de stove noddin', en de whole kitchen look like it been tored up by a harrycane. I des shuck her up, I did, en tell her dat if dat de way she gwine do, she better go 'long back en stay wid her mam-my.
speaker: Jesse

utterance: Well, you are very meddlesome. I don't understand you at all. Who is going to cook breakfast?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Mistiss, I done tell you dat breakfus is all ready en a-waitin', I made dat gal set de table, en dey ain't nothin' ter do but put de vittles on it.
speaker: Jesse

utterance: These biscuits are very well cooked. But there are too many of them. My daughter, we must pinch and save; it will only be for a little while. We must have the old Place back; we must rake and scrape, and save money and buy it back. And this coffee is very good, too, it has quite the old flavor. I thought the girl was too young, but she's a good cook-a very good cook indeed.
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: Ah, yes, I saw him in the yard. And he used to belong to the Bas-coms? Well, well, it must have been a long time ago. This is Jesse behind me? Stand out there, Jesse, and let me look at you. Ah, yes, a likely negro; a very likely negro indeed. And what Bascom did you belong to, Jesse? Merriwether Bas-com! Why, to be sure; why, certainly!
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: Why, of course, Merriwether Bascom. Well, well, I remember him distinctly. A rough-and-tumble sort of man he was, fighting, gambling, horse-racing, always on the wing. A good man at bottom, but wild. And so you belonged to Merriwether Bas-com? Well, boy, once a Bascom always a Bascom. We'll have the old Place back, Jesse, we'll have it back: but we must pinch ourselves; we must save.
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: The barn is painted red. I think olive green would be prettier.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: No, we will have the barn removed. It was not there in my time. It is an innovation. We will have it removed a mile away from the house. We will make many changes. There are hundreds of acres in the meadow yonder that ought to be in cotton. In my time we tried to kill grass, but this man is doing his best to propagate it. Look at that field of Ber-muda there. Two years of hard work will be required to get the grass out.
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: This is Judge Bascom, I presume. My name is Underwood. I am glad to meet you.
speaker: Mr. Francis Underwood

utterance: This is my daughter, Mr. Underwood
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: My dog has paid you a great compliment, Miss Bascom. He makes few friends, and I have never before seen him sacrifice his dignity to his enthusiasm.
speaker: Mr. Francis Underwood

utterance: I feel highly flattered by his attentions. I have read some-where, or heard it said, that the instincts of a little child and a dog are unerring.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I imagine that instinct has little to do with the matter. I prefer to believe- Did you know, sir, that this place, all these lands, once belonged to me?
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: Yes. I knew the place once be-longed to you, and I have been somewhat proud of the fact. We still call it the Bas-com Place, you know.
speaker: Mr. Francis Underwood

utterance: I should think so! I should think so! Pray what else could it be called?
speaker: Briscoe Bascom

utterance: Well, it might have been called Grass-lands, you know, or The Poplars, but some-how the old name seemed to suit it best. I like to think of it as the Bascom Place.
speaker: Mr. Francis Underwood

utterance: You are right, sir, you are right, sir. It is the Bascom Place. All the powers of earth cannot strip us of our name.
speaker: Briscoe Bascom
